posts.cooked: Our mentor has had this idea for a while now—to take a high-end computer mouse and use it for tracking the robot's position on the field. We’ve even discussed using multiple mice; however, I’ve heard this idea brought up several times during my time on the team, but we’ve never pursued it further. In theory, the purpose of a mouse is designed to track location and provide that data to the computer. While it doesn’t seem like a massive challenge, I’d appreciate your thoughts on whether this is a viable idea. Additionally, I wonder if anyone else has attempted something similar and would like to share any suggestions for improving the localization process.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: This comes up regularly, though it isn’t very practical due to several issues. The mouse must be very close to the ground, which makes it prone to damage and potential interference (FOD) on the field. Mice aren’t capable of tracking at the high speeds robots travel at, even though they’ve improved over time, so checking specifications for the specific mouse is important.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
That’s a fantastic idea! I think you’d really enjoy exploring it.  

The general approach used by optical mice is known as “Optical Flow” [citation needed]: it involves capturing high-framerate, low-resolution images, identifying distinctive points within these images, and tracking their movement across successive frames.  

You can purchase a breakout board featuring a typical mouse sensor, but with a specialized lens designed to focus farther away. Experimenting with this setup could be quite enjoyable. However, there’s a limitation to these sensors: they rely on sufficient overlap between consecutive frames for accurate feature matching. The PMW3901 sensor operates at a maximum speed of 7 radians per second, which allows for some basic calculations to determine the appropriate distance from the floor for optimal performance.  

Additionally, you can implement the Optical Flow algorithm using a standard camera paired with OpenCV [citation needed]. While the resulting frame rate may be relatively low, it provides a straightforward method for gaining insight into how the algorithm functions.  

If you’re interested in applying this technology to the ceiling instead of the floor, I have some regional ceiling video examples available for review [citation needed]. Keep in mind that the ceiling’s non-flat surface (with trusses and other structures) introduces complexities due to potential curvature and structural irregularities.  

Good luck with your project!

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked: This is actually a pretty common thing in this context, however it works a lot better on that scale when you're moving at a much lower speed and closer to the ground.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: I’ve looked at using optical flow sensors pointed at the ceiling as well, but they aren’t as accurate since the ceiling at most venues isn’t a uniform surface. Right now, I’m looking at using a different stereo camera setup to have accurate pose estimation.

Exploring the use of an Oak D lite and Spectacular AI for localization

posts.name: JacobD
posts.cooked: This is called an optical flow sensor. This technology has been adapted to drones recently and provides sensors with very high precision for that application. I've been considering whether a sensor could be mounted upward rather than downward to track the ceiling of a building. I bought one to test this idea but haven't acted on it yet.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Also, because it's a mouse, it will only tell you how it moved relative to where it started, so you need to "seed" its initial pose using some other method, like with AprilTags.

When placing the mouse on suspenduations like an FTC bot odometry, additionally, I’ve read that mice have a range of distance controlled via drivers, though it’s quite shallow by default. At home, I have a laser Razer mouse that isn’t very costly and boasts a speck rating of 300 IPS (Inches Per Second), which equates to approximately 7.62 m/s—a speed often seen in FRC (First Robotics Competition) robots. Therefore, I believe we could potentially acquire a more advanced mouse at a reasonable price.
I referenced a laser mouse that works differently compared to an optical mouse and uses an optical flow sensor.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Then it might work, though you’d have to stay aware of the Field Operating Distance (FOD) on the field and protect the mouse module from damage. Ideally, you’d like a way to confirm whether the mouse sensor is within range of a surface and tracking accurately versus not, so you can trust the data selectively based on its condition at the moment.

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked: The TPU90A Grippy Tire CAD has been published finally. I now realize that discussing the carpet was a mistake. I’ve also had similar experiences, featuring a prototype on my desk utilizing a refocused ADNS3080 mouse sensor, an LED illumination system, and a VL6180X distance sensor. The latter is essential due to the need to precisely measure optical distances.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.cooked: Yeah, of course, it wouldn’t be the only way; it would calibrate itself using April tags and a Kalman filter.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: I also worry about years where the floor has obstacles, such as cable runs and other game elements. This year will be surprisingly simple because the carpet is a flat surface only.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: If you're wondering whether sticking a "COTS mouse" onto the robot will work, I believe there might be some concerns, particularly given a flat carpet scenario. Perhaps trying it out could be worthwhile. Additionally, regarding your question, while both laser and optical mice operate similarly in terms of their sensing mechanisms, the laser functions as an illumination source rather than being a sensor itself. For further details, refer to [the provided link](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_mouse#Laser_mice).

posts.name: Tristan Lall
posts.cooked: A discussion on optical mouse navigation took place approximately 20 years ago. I'm not sure of the ultimate result.

Essentially, the difference between using a mouse and a system like omnidirectional wheels is that the latter allows visibility, such as seen at FTC competitions, where there’s no slipping and no fear of losing traction. I believe this approach would function effectively during the last two seasons when we faced no obstacles and operated in open fields.
I think technology-wise and software-wise, discussions about topics spanning 20 years don't seem very relevant.

Not super common in FIRST Tech Challenge (FTC) yet, but it’s growing. This year, we had the first widely adopted Commercial, off-the-shelf (COTS) application from Sparkfun, specifically their Optical Tracking Odometry Sensor. The sensor performs well for our team, tracking up to at least 15 FPS, though one downside is that it must be positioned at least 10mm above the floor.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: The PAA5160E1 appears to be a superior sensor compared to the PMW3901. The datasheet [1] states a maximum speed of 2.5 m/s, while my earlier claim suggests double that amount, which is intriguing. What occurs when pushed to that limit? Is it equally accurate?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
I played around with this idea back in 2019 after discovering that my laser mouse tracked exceptionally well on both plastic and carpet surfaces during that year's game.

However, despite its promise, there are notable limitations to using optical flow sensors in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) robots:

1. **Optics**: Ideally, you'd want a 1"-2" gap between the laser emitter and the floor to avoid mechanical adjustments. Currently, commercially available optical flow sensors either fall short at distances less than 0.1 inches or extend beyond 12 inches, leaving a significant gap. Modifying existing sensors to achieve this range is challenging and inconsistent across multiple units.

2. **Multiple Sensors Required**: Optical Flow sensors primarily track horizontal movements, necessitating placement on multiple corners of the robot for reliable tracking. This increases complexity and cost compared to simpler wheel-based solutions.

3. **Custom Telemetry Code**: Implementing optical flow systems often requires custom software solutions, potentially needing a co-processor to manage input effectively. Established sensor platforms offer pre-packaged, easier-to-implement alternatives.

4. **Modern Solutions Outperform**: Advances in encoder and gyro odometry, combined with April Tags, allow FRC teams to achieve sub-inch accuracy. Only in specialized scenarios involving slippery surfaces might optical flow prove advantageous, though such cases are rare.

While I acknowledge the potential of commercial optical flow sensors, their current requirements make them impractical given the technical and financial challenges involved.

This year, Sparkfun introduced a COTS optical tracking sensor that performs well at 15 FPS, though it must be positioned just 10mm above the floor—a constraint worth noting if you're considering its integration into your project.
